item.title: Carl T. Bergstrom
item.description: There’s a common story that, loosely speaking, the replication crisis occurs when publication bias and questionable research practices fill the literature with false positives. That story motivates a lot of science reform efforts — and it’s wrong. We explain why in our new (well, extensively rewritten) preprint:https://osf.io/preprints/socarxiv/rkyf7(I'll try to expand this into a proper thread soon.)

item.title: Richard Murphy
item.description: A worldwide wealth tax? Why do it, when local progress would be so much easier? https://www.taxresearch.org.uk/Blog/2024/06/26/a-worldwide-wealth-tax-why-do-it-when-local-progress-would-be-so-much-easier/ We could, in theory, have a worldwide wealth tax, give or take up to 20 years of negotiation to get it, only to find it did not work. Or we could close the loopholes in existing laws in local tax regimes around the world and collect considerably more tax. I know what I would choose.

item.title: David C. Norris
item.description:
It turns out there is a lower bound on the skewness 𝑔₁ of any strictly positive set of data having a given mean μ and standard deviation σ: 𝑔₁ > σ/μ – μ/σ.Although discussed as a fresh result in some recent literature, it seems to me likely ancient — for reasons I outlined in this @PubPeer post https://pubpeer.com/publications/276A6F96A7A1E99D5A442233E092AB#1.Perhaps somebody here has long been familiar with this result, or can even identify its vintage?
@ColinTheMathmo
